unnormalised: New Delhi: A major goof-up has come to light after citizens attempting to access vital government services discovered discrepancies in official address listings. The issue seems to stem from a recent consolidation drive, with many addresses simply being "updated" without proper verification.
normalised: New Delhi: A major goof-up has come to light after citizens attempting to access vital government services discovered discrepancies in official address listings. The issue seems to stem from a recent consolidation drive, with many addresses simply being "updated" without proper verification.

unnormalised: Take, for example, the case of the Central Board of Secondary Education, or CBSE as we know it. Its official HQ address, as listed on several govt. websites, is now showing up as "Shiksha Kendra, 2, Community Centre, Preet Vihar, Delhi-110092." But, residents are pointing out that the CBSE's main office shifted years ago. Trying to reach the “Shiksha Kendra” for urgent document verification has become a nightmare for some students, with many running around like headless chickens.
normalised: Take, for example, the case of the Central Board of Secondary Education, or C-B-S-E as we know it. Its official H-Q address, as listed on several government websites, is now showing up as "Shiksha Kendra, two, Community Centre, Preet Vihar, Delhi-one hundred and ten thousand and ninety two." But, residents are pointing out that the C-B-S-E's main office shifted years ago. Trying to reach the “Shiksha Kendra” for urgent document verification has become a nightmare for some students, with many running around like headless chickens.

unnormalised: The Department of Telecommunications (DoT) is facing a similar problem. Their website lists its headquarters at “Sanchar Bhawan, 20, Ashoka Road, New Delhi - 110001." While the Sanchar Bhawan building itself is correct, citizens report that specific departments within DoT have relocated within the building, making it difficult to locate the right office without internal contacts. "I spent nearly 2 hrs. just trying to find the licensing section," complained one entrepreneur.
normalised: The Department of Telecommunications (D-o-T) is facing a similar problem. Their website lists its headquarters at “Sanchar Bhawan, twenty, Ashoka Road, New Delhi - one hundred and ten thousand and one." While the Sanchar Bhawan building itself is correct, citizens report that specific departments within D-o-T have relocated within the building, making it difficult to locate the right office without internal contacts. "I spent nearly two hours just trying to find the licensing section," complained one entrepreneur.

unnormalised: Then there’s the story of the National Informatics Centre (NIC), which, according to its online presence, resides at "A-Block, Lodhi Road, New Delhi, 110003." While broadly correct, the building houses multiple other agencies. New visitors often end up wandering through the maze-like corridors, asking for directions at every turn. Better signage is definitely needed bhai!
normalised: Then there’s the story of the National Informatics Centre (N-I-C), which, according to its online presence, resides at "A-Block, Lodhi Road, New Delhi, one hundred and ten thousand and three." While broadly correct, the building houses multiple other agencies. New visitors often end up wandering through the maze-like corridors, asking for directions at every turn. Better signage is definitely needed bhai!

unnormalised: Even institutions like AIIMS (All India Institute of Medical Sciences), while centrally located, suffer from outdated block and ward designations in their official addresses. Imagine someone rushing their loved one to the emergency and spending valuable time trying to decipher which entrance corresponds to "Gate No. 4, Trauma Centre, AIIMS, New Delhi - 110029.” Time is of the essence in such situations!
normalised: Even institutions like A-I-I-M-S (All India Institute of Medical Sciences), while centrally located, suffer from outdated block and ward designations in their official addresses. Imagine someone rushing their loved one to the emergency and spending valuable time trying to decipher which entrance corresponds to "Gate Number four, Trauma Centre, A-I-I-M-S, New Delhi - one hundred and ten thousand and twenty nine.” Time is of the essence in such situations!

unnormalised: Postal service efficiency is also taking a hit. With incomplete or inaccurate addresses, deliveries are getting delayed, adding to the woes of citizens who rely on prompt communication for official purposes. "My passport application got returned because the address on my form didn't exactly match what the post office had on record for the regional passport office at Bhikaji Cama Place, New Delhi - 110066," lamented a frustrated applicant.
normalised: Postal service efficiency is also taking a hit. With incomplete or inaccurate addresses, deliveries are getting delayed, adding to the woes of citizens who rely on prompt communication for official purposes. "My passport application got returned because the address on my form didn't exactly match what the post office had on record for the regional passport office at Bhikaji Cama Place, New Delhi - one hundred and ten thousand and sixty six," lamented a frustrated applicant.

unnormalised: Experts are urging the government to conduct a comprehensive audit of all official addresses and implement a centralized database that is regularly updated. They suggest integrating GPS coordinates into address listings to facilitate easier navigation.
normalised: Experts are urging the government to conduct a comprehensive audit of all official addresses and implement a centralized database that is regularly updated. They suggest integrating G-P-S coordinates into address listings to facilitate easier navigation.

unnormalised: Until a proper solution is implemented, citizens are advised to cross-verify address information from multiple sources before sending important documents or visiting government offices. Let's hope the babus get their act together soon, or else we are all doomed!
normalised: Until a proper solution is implemented, citizens are advised to cross-verify address information from multiple sources before sending important documents or visiting government offices. Let's hope the babus get their act together soon, or else we are all doomed!
